Subject: English Language
ParentText: English - English Language

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Construct a mind map of the various functions of language and identify various situations in which these functions are achieved.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Investigate theories about animal communication in nature, e.g. bees, dolphins, chimpanzees, and compare with human communication. What are the characteristics that make human communication different and unique?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Develop a text for a specific situation (for example, writing a letter from a charity organisation asking for a donation) and reflect on the language choices made.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Discuss the impact of modern communication technology on the traditional spoken and written modes of language.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: List the various ways we address and refer to individuals in our family and community, for example, life-partner, mother / father, doctor, grandparents, friends, colleagues etc. and discuss what these language choices reveal about a person's values, attitudes and beliefs.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Examine the ritualistic language of ceremonies such as weddings, baptisms and funerals or the language of the courts, medicine and other professions. Comment on how language choices are influenced by the context, both situation and cultural.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Gather evidence of how advertising a certain product has changed over time. For example, a car, mobile phone, cleaning products etc. Comment on how the nature and functions of language have changed over the years.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Research media for examples of complaints or observations about language use; for example, letters to the editor; set up a folder / journal; for each example, identify the language feature being discussed or the subsystem referred to; keep adding to journal throughout year.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Explore some grammar resources (books and websites) and complete some grammar exercises and activities on subsystems and debate the importance of linguistic structures and rules in effective communication.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Using three different sample texts (written, spoken, digital), break down the words into the various word classes; arrange the words in a table, list or mind map.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Make a list of as many prefixes as possible; identify the meaning of each prefix; list three words for each prefix; consider whether each word has meaning without the prefix. Use key concepts and metalanguage appropriately to describe and analyse language use in an objective and a systematic way through spoken and written Australian texts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Collect a range of text types in the written mode to explore how the language choices made in those texts are influenced by the function, tenor and contexts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Collect a range of text types in the written mode to explore how the language choices made in those texts are influenced by the function, tenor and contexts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: For example:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Students collect two types of writing: an advertisement on a food item and an informative food label; compare both types, exploring how they are similar or different in terms of language choice

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Students collect recipes aimed at children and recipes aimed at adults and analyse how language differs when it is aimed at different audiences

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - The nature and functions of language
ExampleText: Students compare a spoken recipe with a written recipe and analyse how different modes influence different language choices.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Identify and use key linguistic concepts and theories as they relate to language acquisition.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Challenge students to draw or download an image of a cross-section of a vocal tract' and demonstrate specific manners and places of articulation.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Conduct a class debate to evaluate the various theories of language acquisition.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Produce a pamphlet or poster to promote one or more theories of language acquisition.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Investigate what children need to acquire as they develop as users of spoken language in the critical period, including how they acquire language knowledge and how they learn to use language for a range of functions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Create an illustrated flowchart of the developmental stages of language acquisition, including age ranges, examples of language use, key subsystem involvement.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Co-create a match-up game of child language examples and associated metalanguage (such as over-generalisation) and play in small groups.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Experience and interpret linguistic fieldwork, including data collection.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Investigate 'feral children' and create a fact sheet about the phenomenon.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Conduct a panel interview of people who have grown up multilingual or are raising their children to be multilingual. Construct a report on the findings from the panel interview.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Construct a case study about Sophie Li - investigate her journey from birth with profound hearing loss to living with a cochlear implant.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Interview an expert in reading recovery or learning disabilities (such as a literacy, inclusion or disability leader) at your school to investigate the impacts and strategies to support students with delayed or impacted language development.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Use and interpret language samples of first- and additional-language acquisition, to interpret child language user samples:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Using the IPA, write a coded message to a classmate and then have them decipher it
ParentText: Use and interpret language samples of first- and additional-language acquisition, to interpret child language user samples:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Transcribe short recordings of child language use using the IPA and appropriate transcription symbols
ParentText: Use and interpret language samples of first- and additional-language acquisition, to interpret child language user samples:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Translate a range of IPA riddles
ParentText: Use and interpret language samples of first- and additional-language acquisition, to interpret child language user samples:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Read and analyse transcriptions of child language use and evaluate the stage of language development using the transcription as evidence.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Linguistic Investigation / Fieldwork

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText:
Determine a research question related to an element of the key knowledge, for example: 
What characteristics of language acquisition are evident in children at a particular period?
This question can be further refined and tested by the fieldwork / investigation, for example:
How do samples of language use by children between the ages of two and three support the theory of Universal Grammar?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText:
Determine subjects for study, for example:
Clips of children speaking on YouTube or another online site, siblings, friends, children at an early childhood centre or kindergarten.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText:
Discuss and explore the issues of consent. If observing children in family or educational settings that are not online, how do you organise permission. 
For more detailed information about seeking consent, see the Fieldwork implementation on-demand video

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Determine relevant data to be collected. This can include observational notes based on non-invasive observations and / or recordings.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText: Review data collection, annotate notes and transcribe recordings if desired.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Language acquisition
ExampleText:
Develop a summary of findings based on analysis of data and consider in light of the original question.
Produce a short report based on the fieldwork process

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Use key linguistic concepts and metalanguage as they relate to the changing nature of English. Construct a graphic organiser or mind map of key changes in each subsystem over time from Old to Modern English.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Identify and describe language change in an objective and a systematic way:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Compare various versions of the Lord's Prayer from Old to Modern English - annotate with morphological, semantic and syntactic differences
ParentText: Identify and describe language change in an objective and a systematic way:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Construct an animated timeline of the development of English from IE to Modern English
ParentText: Identify and describe language change in an objective and a systematic way:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Map the major developments of English from IE to Modern English - including key factors from Incursions and Inventions electives. Connect the events on the map chronologically with arrows.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Construct an interactive quiz in Kahoot or PowerPoint to quiz classmates on entirety, or an aspect of chosen elective option.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Create an infographic which summarises the key linguistic influences of each topic within the chosen elective option.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Trace etymologies in appropriate sources, such as databases and etymological dictionaries.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: As a class, co-construct a family tree of Indo-European Languages with each language represented on an annotated leaf and each language family represented on a branch. Allocate one language per student to independently research and then challenge the class to construct the tree.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Provide students with a range of German, Dutch, Danish and English cognates and see if students can analyse their morphology and then group them according to their meaning.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Allocate each student an interesting word and have them trace its etymology. Co-construct a classroom word wall of interesting etymologies of English words, paying close attention to morphological and semantic changes over time and factors which influenced these. These words is an interesting place to start.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Analyse changes in the English language over time as reflected in texts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Provide students with a range of texts from various eras of English and have them organise them chronologically. See Text samples.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Develop a fact file of key information about each topic in the chosen elective option.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Annotate language and text examples, noting significant morphological, semantic, syntactical and / or phonological features; construct a written analysis which synthesises the features of language in the sample and the contextual factors which influenced its linguistic features.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Collect and annotate examples of texts from:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Each major event in the Incursion elective
ParentText: Collect and annotate examples of texts from:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Each major development in the Invention elective
ParentText: Collect and annotate examples of texts from:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Apply and analyse knowledge of the evolution of English in consideration of prescriptivism and descriptivism.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Have students analyse the morphology of prescriptivism and descriptivism. Discuss the characteristics of each word and its meaning.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Have students place themselves on a continuum of prescriptivist to descriptivist and discuss their reasons.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Show the class the 21st Century Flux spoken word poem by Dizraeli; Use this to initiate a class discussion about prescriptivism and descriptivism.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Develop a fact file of key information about each topic in the chosen elective option.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Each fact file could contain:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: A Cornell notetaking sheet for each topic:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Students undertake guided reading or guided research on each topic
ParentText: A Cornell notetaking sheet for each topic:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: This could be jigsawed in groups and then collated
ParentText: A Cornell notetaking sheet for each topic:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Annotated texts for each topic, demonstrating the influences on language:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Students could access their own texts or have these provided
ParentText: Annotated texts for each topic, demonstrating the influences on language:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Using a gradual release model, support student annotations of texts
ParentText: Annotated texts for each topic, demonstrating the influences on language:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: Subsystems provide a framework for the nature of annotations, in addition to contextual factors organised around technological, socio-cultural and socio-political concepts
ParentText: Annotated texts for each topic, demonstrating the influences on language:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: A written analysis which synthesises each topic into a cohesive summary, using annotated texts as evidence:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - English across time
ExampleText: This could be a guided analytical commentary, or structured as a research essay.
ParentText: A written analysis which synthesises each topic into a cohesive summary, using annotated texts as evidence:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Identify and use key linguistic concepts as they relate to the development of English as a world language.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Conduct a classroom discussion on the following questions: If English is not your first language, why did you learn it, or give it a special status? Why is it given a special status in some countries? What does the term English mean to you and to people in the communities you belong to? Do you use English exclusively, or do you use other languages for some / many purposes? Would you say that you love English or have pride in it? Do you feel that its use is imposed on you? Are you happy to 'subvert' it or do you think you should respect its codified norms? And other languages you know?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Select two countries colonised by Britain, for example, Australia and India? How is English used in those countries today and what is its status? Which language features still survive from the time of colonisation in those countries? What happened to the original languages? Is English in these countries spoken differently? Make a table to show the differences between the language used in countries then and now and explain the differences.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Use the subsystems of language to analyse language in written and spoken texts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Collect examples of unusual use of English, which may be found in overseas advertising, product descriptions or tourism and explore the reasons that may have led to this unusual nature of language use.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Create a text (spoken or written) in a variety of English spoken by, for example, Italian speakers or Sinhalese speakers or Vietnamese speakers or Chinese speakers or African speakers etc.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Interpret and explain debates about language change and influence.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Research and list countries where English is spoken as:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: First (or native) language (ENL) - Inner Circle
ParentText: Research and list countries where English is spoken as:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: English as Second Language (ESL) - Outer Circle
ParentText: Research and list countries where English is spoken as:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: English as Foreign Language (EFL) - Expanding Circle
ParentText: Research and list countries where English is spoken as:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Identify and apply key concepts related to language maintenance, shift, reclamation, change and loss.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Research the history and the role of Tok Pisin in Papua New Guinea today. When, where and by whom is it used? How important is it for the national identity of PNG?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Explore the impact of teaching or testing Indigenous students using standardised language or standardised testing instead of teaching them in the variety of English that they are familiar with or speak.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Analyse distinctive features of Aboriginal English in poems like 'The Rainbow Serpent' or other texts written in Aboriginal English.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Explore kinship terms used in different cultures to gain an understanding of how relations are organised differently in each language and present their understanding of how different languages portray the world in different terms.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Present a report highlighting attempts to save Aboriginal languages.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Explore the factors which contribute to the decline and death of a language.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: Create a text (spoken or written) in a variety of English spoken by, for example, Italian speakers or Sinhalese speakers or Vietnamese speakers or Chinese speakers or African speakers etc. Students can choose from a wide range of domains (for example, food, travel, festival etc.) and text types or genre (advertisement, a poem, a short story, an interview, travel guide or information brochure etc.) to create the texts. Their texts must be accompanied by:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: An explanation of how the cultural context influences the language features [lexical choices, syntax, semantics, discourse features etc.]

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: An analysis of how it varies from Standard English

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Englishes in contact
ExampleText: A commentary on how this variety maintains its distinctiveness and functions as a marker of identity for its users.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: General introduction to formality / informality

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: List a range of synonyms for a particular word, for example inebriated, using a thesaurus to help; arrange the synonyms along a continuum from most informal to most formal; discuss the connotations of each expression; in which context is each word more likely to be heard or used?

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Consider spoken, written and digital texts from within a given domain, for example sport; arrange the texts from least formal to most formal; discuss how the structure and content of these texts is influenced by the situational and cultural context of each.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Role-play the different ways in which people ask for things to be done, for example when asking someone to close a door; classify these requests into sentence types: is the request imperative, interrogative, declarative or exclamative? Discuss which sentence types are appropriate in certain situations and the impact on participants' face needs.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Brainstorm and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of speech and writing; have a class debate about which mode is the most prestigious in our society.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Role-play everyday conversations between friends or family members in which one speaker deliberately uses formal language; what effect does this have on the flow and outcome of the conversation, and the impact on participants' face needs?

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Discuss levels of formality in a semi-scripted conversation, for example in interview / chat shows; place the language within the continuum formal to informal, and refer to features of informal and formal language.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Collect images of people in various clothing - formal suits / dresses, sportswear, businesswear, casual / neat casual - and have students arrange them from most formal to least formal. Ask how they decided: appropriateness for an occasion? Length of dress / skirt / pants / shirt sleeves? Tie or no tie? Jeans or no jeans? Connect to the language that we use in different contexts and how it must also be appropriate.

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Take notes (or record with permission) during three different school-based conversations, such as:

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: In class between student and teacher
ParentText: Take notes (or record with permission) during three different school-based conversations, such as:

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: In class between student and student
ParentText: Take notes (or record with permission) during three different school-based conversations, such as:

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: At lunch between student and student
ParentText: Take notes (or record with permission) during three different school-based conversations, such as:

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: Between student and coordinator / principal / other school leader
ParentText: Take notes (or record with permission) during three different school-based conversations, such as:

Subject: English Language
ExampleText: How does the differing tenor in each situation affect the register?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Record and transcribe a short segment of a television program and examine the features of spontaneous spoken language and, in multimodal texts, examine the importance of body language and paralinguistic cues. Suitable programs could include The Project, Q&A, You Can't Ask That, Frankly, One Plus One, The Cook Up with Adam Liaw.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Examine a transcript of a telephone conversation or a segment of talkback radio and discuss the significance of back channelling and other strategies in spoken discourse.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Use YouTube to listen to the stand-up routines of comedians, for example at the annual Melbourne International Comedy Festival

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Discuss why most comedians use informal language features in their prepared routines; current Australian comedians can include: Steph Tisdell, Nazeem Hussein, Celia Pacquola, Jordan Raskopoulos, Hannah Gadsby, Tom Ballard.
ParentText: Use YouTube to listen to the stand-up routines of comedians, for example at the annual Melbourne International Comedy Festival

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: What effect does the use of informal language have on their audience and the success of their routine?
ParentText: Use YouTube to listen to the stand-up routines of comedians, for example at the annual Melbourne International Comedy Festival

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Consider when, how and why we 'play' with language when interacting with small children, friends, family members and partners

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: What innovative words or catchphrases are unique to students' families or friendship groups?
ParentText: Consider when, how and why we 'play' with language when interacting with small children, friends, family members and partners

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Write a list of expressions that are particular to a workplace or other professions which would not be considered Standard English; discuss when and why these words are used.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Examine the Classification website and discuss the issue of swearing; consider how words can lose their intensifying effect over time.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Explore the characteristics and features of informal texts through a specific field.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Read some of Danny Katz's writing in The Age newspaper; in groups, discuss the language features and structures which contribute to the informal register which is characteristic of Katz's writing.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Select two students to discuss an interesting event which occurred recently, for example a party or school formal, and record this conversation; have one student write down an account of the same event; use the account and the recording to examine the syntactic and discourse features of the two texts, noting the differences between speech and writing; students could then accurately transcribe the conversation, using accepted notation.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Look at Instagram posts for Pride Month from accounts such as RainbowRoo or Minus18. Examine how these organisations use informal language to meet the positive face needs of their readers / followers.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Watch an episode of Hard Chat on YouTube. Examine how Tom Gleeson challenges his guests' positive face needs within the comedic context of the 'interview'.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Analyse the effect informal contexts have on language choices, exploring identified online communities, like Reddit.'

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Characteristics and features of informal texts

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: As a class, list written and spoken texts from within a specific field. Students could contribute to deciding on the field but ideas include the weather, travel, fashion and health.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: The field of health, for example, could use text samples from government Health advice, a short extract from the Health Report, a posting on a wellness blog, a short extract from a wellness podcast, or a recording of a conversation between friends.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: In pairs, plot these texts along a continuum from most informal to most formal, and be prepared to justify the continuum in the classroom selection.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Discuss how the situational and cultural context of each text influences its structure and language.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Listen to a recording of an informal spoken text from the field of your choice. In the example of health, consider an extract from a wellness podcast.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Transcribe a section and annotate, identifying the features of spoken language referred to in the study design.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Discuss the link between the spoken language features and the context of the transcript.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Write up notes into an extended analytical commentary.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Analyse the effect of informal contexts on language choices.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Analyse the characteristics and features of informal spoken English.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Investigate a subreddit (a specific community or topic within Reddit):

Subject: English Language

ExampleText: R / AustralianPolitics

ExampleText: R / australianwildlife

ExampleText: R / AustralianMakeup

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: R / AusMentalHealth
ParentText: Investigate a subreddit (a specific community or topic within Reddit):

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Select conversations from within two different subreddits.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Note down language that seems to be specific to that community, and language that reflects the online context.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Discuss the different language used in the different subreddits and whether, despite the potentially serious nature of some of them (such as those to do with politics or finance), the language is still more likely to be informal due to the online context.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Informality
ExampleText: Write a report discussing the various language features of subreddits.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: In groups, select examples of formal language from a field such as education; discuss why a formal register has been used in each of these texts and the possible impact on participants' face needs: textbooks, school website and song, reports, Principal's assembly speech, parental correspondence, behaviour contracts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Collect samples of texts in a formal register from domains which generate a range of formal language texts, including the law and government; read and examine the Victorian Charter of Human Rights and Responsibilities; list in a tabular format the language features of the charter across each of the subsystems; present findings to the class as an oral presentation, short recording (audio or audio visual), PowerPoint presentation, poster or analytical commentary.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: After close reading, write an analysis of semantic patterning of a literary text; this could include extracts from poetry, novels and plays. Semantic patterning includes figurative language, irony, metaphor, oxymoron, simile, hyperbole, personification, animation, puns, lexical ambiguity.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Identify and discuss the phonological patterning of a ballad or a hymn.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Investigate the language characteristic in 'oaths', such as the 'Olympic Oath', 'Scouting Promise' or 'Australia's Pledge of Commitment' for new citizens, and how the language reflects the situational and cultural contexts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: The War Memorial's website
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Kevin Rudd's Apology to Australia's Indigenous Peoples
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Paul Keating's Redfern Address 1993
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: The Uluru Statement from the Heart
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Anthony Albanese's Garma speech
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Julia Gillard's misogyny speech
ParentText: Read a legal document such as a will, a building contract or a piece of legislation and discuss the common sentence types used, how cohesion and coherence are achieved, and the use of any jargon; discuss the prevalence of coordinating conjunctions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Discuss the syntactic patterning present, as well as the use of semantic features; write an essay explaining the role of these semantic and syntactic patterns in creating coherence and cohesion, and how they enhance the overall effect of the speech.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: In small groups, compile a list of all the words and phrases used in society today to describe 'death' and 'sex'; decide which are euphemisms and which are dysphemisms, and discuss the different connotations of each.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Consider changes being made to the original language of, for example, Roald Dahl's books regarding appearance and gender. Other authors whose texts have undergone similar treatment include Agatha Christie and Ian Fleming. Consider the implications of changing original language in terms of negotiating social taboos or promoting social harmony, against the preservation of literature written in different times and contexts. Students could read extracts from the original version of a novel and compare the language that has been changed in the revised version.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Using on online thesaurus tool, list a range of words and phrases to express sympathy and condolences and examine their typical linguistic features.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Create and transcribe conversations dealing with embarrassing or difficult topics, such as body odour, sacking an employee, breaking off a relationship, a parent / teacher interview, criticising another's actions; discuss the language features used, including euphemisms and other politeness strategies, and how these facilitate such interactions and assist in meeting face needs.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Compare the way that the same event (particularly something of a dramatic nature, such as a natural disaster, a death or a crime) is reported in a range of different media (print and digital); examine how lexical and syntactic choices in particular reveal assumptions about readers' values and general knowledge. Also examine how different media groups show respect / empathy / bias / neutrality.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Examine and analyse the language used in the websites of the major Australian political parties; explore the varying levels of formality and the way language is used positively and negatively to promote a certain point of view.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Investigate media releases presented by the Premier or Prime Minister on different topics. (These are published on their websites.) How does their language change depending on the perceived seriousness of the issue being presented?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Write an essay on a topic related to the use of formal language, for example 'In this age of digital communication, is formal language an endangered species in Australian society?'

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Examine newspaper headlines for examples of passive voice and nominalisation. For example 'Player injured, Melbourne derby abandoned after violent pitch invasion' (The Age, 17 December, 2022). What effect does the use of passive voice and / or nominalisation have in headlines?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Students identify ways that they use jargon in their workplace, sport, school subjects and hobbies. How does it enable them to communicate more clearly, precisely and quickly? Consider how it allows them to show their expertise in their workplace etc.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Explore the characteristics and features of formal texts through a government website.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Characteristics and features of formal texts

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Go to the website of the Australian War Memorial and list different examples of formal language. These could include the Privacy and Copyright statements as well as information about the Memorial's history and activities.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Pick one text and analyse the discourse and language features which contribute to this text's formal register. Consider lexicon, including jargon; sentence types and structures; use of passive voice; information flow; and politeness strategies.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: In groups, discuss how the language in various sections of the website is carefully constructed to present a positive image of Australia's war involvement. Present findings to the class.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Listen to the audio and read the transcript of Kevin Rudd's Apology to Australia's Indigenous Peoples speech 2008, Paul Keating's Remembrance Speech 1993 or The Uluru Statement from the Heart.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Discuss the syntactic patterning present in each text, as well as the use of semantic features.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Write an essay explaining the role of these semantic and syntactic patterns in creating coherence and cohesion, and how they enhance the overall effect of the text.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Investigate the use of euphemistic language in news media

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Collect a range of headlines that use euphemistic language. Examples could be language like '2GB terminates Chris Smith's contract after Christmas party incident' compared to 'TV and radio presenter Chris Smith sacked from 2GB and Sky News after Christmas party scandal'.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Organise the euphemisms into categories - death, unemployment, sex or sexuality etc.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Which categories are more likely to be referred to euphemistically in news media? Does the news organisation reporting the issue have an impact on the language used, such as online-only news like news.com.au compared to The Age?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Discuss the effect that the euphemistic language has in relation to face needs, social harmony or negotiating taboos.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Formality
ExampleText: Write an analysis of the types of euphemistic language used in news media and what their purposes are.

ExampleText: Ask students to find their own social media text (on, for example, Instagram, BeReal, Snapchat) that displays Australian English and identity; label features with metalanguage and describe how identity is conveyed in the texts.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Examine the use of Aboriginal English on social media and online; label features with metalanguage and describe how identity is conveyed in the texts.

ExampleText: Study a scene from Heartbreak High where they use Aboriginal English and 'eshay speak' alongside Australian English:

ExampleText: In an essay consider the plethora of varieties that make up 'Australian English'

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Explore an advertisement that employs Australian English as a stereotype. Explore the text through at least two subsystems of language and reflect on the construction of an 'Australian identity'

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Explore the language in this video from YouTube by transcribing the video into a spoken text. Turning on closed captioning can assist with this process.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Using metalanguage, analyse the use of at least three features of Australian English. Label these with metalanguage and ensure you link to how they support the wider purpose and intent of the text.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Analyse the use of patterning in this text. Find at least two examples.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: Watch the video again on YouTube and include an annotation of the spoken features. How does this change the reading of the text?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 1 - Language variation in Australian society
ExampleText: In groups, research the use of Australian English in advertising. Find an example from three different generations and compare and contrast. What does this tell you about an evolving or stagnant Australian identity?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Revise and add to the range of definitions for 'identity'. Provide students with a sheet with a circle on it. Ask them to add facets of their own identity as they read the definitions.

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Discuss a variety of identity features that influence the social and personal variation of English in Australia:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Specific examples for close focus include (but are not limited to) age, gender, occupation, interests, socioeconomic, aspiration, sexuality, and education
ParentText: Discuss a variety of identity features that influence the social and personal variation of English in Australia:

ExampleText: Label 'common' features such as phonological differences, lexis use and syntactic differences in each

ExampleText: Consider frequent stereotypes associated with these identities and subsequently the language features attributed to them

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Look at historical and modern theories on language and gender. Lakoff (Language and Women's Place) is a good place to start. Explore critiques of her claim that women use less taboos, such as Do Women Really Demonstrate a Lakoff Power in their Language?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Label the features that are primarily under discussion using metalanguage (e.g. discourse particles)
ParentText: Look at historical and modern theories on language and gender. Lakoff (Language and Women's Place) is a good place to start. Explore critiques of her claim that women use less taboos, such as Do Women Really Demonstrate a Lakoff Power in their Language?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Encourage students to outline one thing they agree with and one thing they challenge
ParentText: Look at historical and modern theories on language and gender. Lakoff (Language and Women's Place) is a good place to start. Explore critiques of her claim that women use less taboos, such as Do Women Really Demonstrate a Lakoff Power in their Language?

ExampleText: Discuss the changing nature of how we address ourselves:

ExampleText: Watch clips from 'Who sounds gay' by David Thorpe. What does his research suggest about idiolects and stereotypes?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Write an essay exploring the notion 'Language has the capacity to demonstrate who we are and where we're going'.

ExampleText: Ask students to add their findings to a collaborative document and create links between shared history, features and connect these to social context.

AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Research your / a sociolect and respond to the following questions:

Subject: English Language

ExampleText: Why is language important in the sphere you have chosen?

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Using your sociolect as an example, respond to the following prompt:

Subject: English Language
AreaofStudy: Area of Study 2 - Individual and group identities
ExampleText: Language has the capacity to reveal facets of who we are and where we belong.
